H0.text: One meter is the distance at which Daphnee would need to place Earth from the Sun in her solar‑system model, where one meter represents one astronomical unit.

H1.text: Two meters is the distance Daphnee must place Earth from the Sun in her model, since one meter represents one astronomical unit (AU).

H2.text: Three meters is the distance from the Sun at which Earth would be placed in Daphnee's model of the solar system, given that she uses a scale of one meter to represent one astronomical unit.

H3.text: Four meters is the distance Daphnee would need to place Earth from the Sun in her model of the solar system, where one meter represents one astronomical unit.

A4.text: The astronomical unit (symbol: au or AU) is a unit of length defined to be exactly equal to 149597870700 m.

A5.text: Earth's average orbital distance is about 150 million km (93 million mi)

A6.text: Jupiter is a 7.5-meter sphere at Stockholm Arlanda Airport, 40 km (25 mi) away.

A7.text: If the Sun–Neptune distance is scaled to 100 metres (330 ft), then the Sun would be about 3 cm (1.2 in) in diameter.

A8.text: The distance between the Sun and the Earth was used to define a unit of length called the astronomical unit, now defined to be 149.5978707×106 kilometres.

A9.text: Its mean distance from Earth is about 1.496×108 kilometres or about 8 light-minutes.
